1) Social distancing
2) Mask usage
3) Isolation of the vulnerable
4) Self quarantine for symptoms
5) Dedicated hospitals for the sick

1/

We need to start opening up the economies ASAP.  To do that we need three inputs from local (i.e. county or town) level:

1) load on hospitals (at/over/under capacity)
2) population density (high/medium/low)
3) # of cases (growing/stable/shrinking)

For #3, we need testing.

If a virus is doubling every three days, then if you respond early you may get away with light measures that can slow its growth and buy the time necessary to test, trace and isolate (e.g. Hong Kong and Singapore).  2/

I guess the key thing is that it appears to me that money is on the same path as music.  Who knows where it will end.\n\nExciting times.

4) Programmable

Music - downloadable; streaming; cut-and-paste production

Money - smart contracts; composable; defi

3) Digital

Music - digitized; recorded on a hard drive

Money - tokenized; governed by cryptography; peer-to-peer

2) Electronic

Music - an analog signal recorded on a cassette tape

Money - a database record in a financial institution

1) Physical

Music - vinyl; wax drum, etc.

Money - cash; gold; written ledger entry, etc

Tokenized securities will bring a wave of financial innovation.  E.g. you could now create a custom security consisting of coupon #5 from bond A, coupon #19 from bond B, coupon #27 from bond C, attach a derivative and offer it to investors that need a unique payout profile.  Wow.
We still need to solve for listing these instruments, secondary markets (who wants to build a DEX), liquidity, privacy, etc.  But these are solvable problems IMHO.
Cryptographic key custody at regulated custodians will play a very important role in these new markets

Tokenized cash from high quality financial institutions is still in its infancy but we will likely see an explosion in bank coins over the coming years.  Longer term, something like @fnality will solve the fungibility problem
On-chain atomic delivery-vs-payment works and has the potential to be extraordinarily useful as a way to reduce the number of intermediaries in a transaction
The security itself still exists as an off-chain legal document that is essentially a set of rights and obligations to certain assets and/or cash flows
It is certainly possible to use a public blockchain for issuing a mainstream security

@fintechyoda I'm not confusing money with currency.  Money has some combination of the following four characteristics: MoE, SoV, UoA & LT.  Currency just happens to be a very specific mix of the four characteristics.

@Melt_Dem With low target inflation rates (2%), well run central banking is designed to solve this problem.  The problem of price stability is a big one and the solution has been to have a variable money supply in response to demand for money.

@Melt_Dem The #1 challenge that all monetary systems have is price stability.  I.e. how to preserve the value of people's money (in the short run anyway) and give them opportunities to invest that money at a rate greater than any inflation that may be occurring.
